stories.text: I just saw that the latest iphone update allows you to unlock the phone with a facemask on, which got me thinking: I'm surprised there haven't been more published exploits that make use of this attack vector. While Apple might have the means to make this relatively robust, I'd suspect the fractured android ecosystem would lead to a lot of half-baked implementations, and the literature on the fragility of ML models w/r/t adversarial input would suggest that even Apple's model should still be susceptible. I recall there being a lot of hubub over police having the tools to crack iOS encryption, which would seem like a harder task than fooling a facial recognition algorithm. How are there so few exploits for facial recognition login floating around?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why isn't biometric (face, finger) login used more for exploits?

stories.text:
Mapcarta.com is an excellent map based on OpenStreetMap (using Mapbox), Wikipedia and Geonames, but I can't find who is working on it or any way to submit bug reports/feedback.

Is there a community around the site somewhere or are they trying to stay private? I'd love to help out if possible.
stories.title: Ask HN: Who is building Mapcarta.com? (an OpenStreetMap viewer)
